title: Costa Rican Indigenous Art

longDescription: Costa Rica is home to eight officially recognized indigenous groups: Boruca, Bribri, Cab√©car, Maleku, Huetar, Chorotega, Teribe (T√©rraba), and Ng√§be. Each community has preserved a unique cultural identity through art, ritual, and craftsmanship. Their creations‚Äîwooden masks, ritual dances, woven baskets, textiles, ceramics, music, and oral storytelling‚Äîreflect not only aesthetic skill but also cosmology, spirituality, and social life. Art has served as a medium of resilience against colonization, a way to transmit knowledge between generations, and a bridge between humans and nature. From the famous Boruca ‚ÄòDance of the Little Devils‚Äô to the sophisticated Chorotega pottery and the sacred Bribri weaving traditions, Costa Rican indigenous art represents a living heritage that continues to inspire both local communities and visitors worldwide.

sections.heading: Information
sections.content: Hand-carved from balsa or cedar, Boruca masks are brightly painted with animal or devil faces. They symbolize ancestral spirits and cultural identity.

sections.heading: Symbolism
sections.content: Masks embody resistance against Spanish conquest and serve as protection for the community.

sections.heading: Technique
sections.content: Made with chisels, sanded, and painted with natural or acrylic pigments.

items.title: Dance of the Little Devils (Danza de los Diablitos)

sections.heading: Overview
sections.content: A three-day ritual (Dec 31‚ÄìJan 2) reenacting the fight between Boruca ‚Äòdevils‚Äô and the Spanish bull, symbolizing indigenous resistance.

sections.heading: Characters
sections.content: The devils wear masks; the bull (toro) represents the Spanish conquerors. Music with drums, flutes, and conch shells accompanies the play.

sections.heading: Cultural Recognition
sections.content: Declared Intangible Cultural Heritage of Costa Rica in 2017.

sections.heading: Information
sections.content: Bribri women create finely woven baskets using natural fibers such as bejuco and chonta palm.

sections.heading: Symbolism
sections.content: Baskets are connected to women‚Äôs role as guardians of knowledge and daily sustenance.

sections.heading: Materials
sections.content: Colored with natural dyes: achiote (orange), nance (red-brown), and other local plants.

sections.heading: Information
sections.content: Cab√©car communities weave textiles and hammocks using cotton and plant fibers.

sections.heading: Cultural Role
sections.content: Textiles are both utilitarian and ceremonial, representing family and clan ties.

sections.heading: Information
sections.content: Chorotega artisans from Guanacaste are famous for pre-Columbian style ceramics with geometric and animal designs.

sections.heading: Techniques
sections.content: Pottery is hand-shaped, burnished, and decorated with slips in red, black, and cream.

sections.heading: Cultural Value
sections.content: Used for rituals, cooking, and trade since ancient times; still produced in Nicoya today.

sections.heading: Information
sections.content: The Maleku, from northern Alajuela, are known for body painting, symbolic drawings on gourds, and ceremonial drums.

sections.heading: Ritual Use
sections.content: Drums accompany ceremonies to honor spirits and nature.

sections.heading: Symbolism
sections.content: Art reflects the Maleku cosmology and the importance of rivers and forests.

sections.heading: Information
sections.content: The Huetar people are associated with the enigmatic stone spheres of Diqu√≠s, declared UNESCO World Heritage.

sections.heading: Cultural Value
sections.content: Spheres may have represented power, astronomy, or ceremonial centers.

sections.heading: Information
sections.content: Ng√§be women create colorful bead necklaces and traditional dresses called naguas.

sections.heading: Cultural Role
sections.content: Dresses represent community identity and are worn in rituals and daily life.

sections.heading: Information
sections.content: All indigenous groups preserve oral traditions‚Äîmyths, legends, songs‚Äîtransmitted across generations.

sections.heading: Instruments
sections.content: Flutes, maracas, drums, and conch shells accompany ceremonies.
